metadata.title: Bronchial epithelial cell extracellular vesicles ameliorate epithelial-mesenchymal transition in COPD pathogenesis by alleviating M2 macrophage polarization

sections.text:
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is partly characterized as epithelial–mesenchymal transition (EMT)-related airflow limitation. Extracellular vesicles (EVs) play crucial roles in the crosstalk between cells, affecting many diseases including COPD. Up to now, the roles of EVs in COPD are still debated. As we found in this investigation, COPD patients have higher miR-21 level in total serum EVs. EMT occurs in lungs of COPD mice. Furthermore, bronchial epithelial cells (BEAS-2B) could generate EVs with less miR-21 when treated with cigarette smoke extract (CSE), impacting less on the M2-directed macrophage polarization than the control-EVs (PBS-treated) according to EVs miR-21 level. Furthermore, the EMT processes in BEAS-2B cells were enhanced with the M2 macrophages proportion when co-cultured. Collectively, these results demonstrate that CSE-treated BEAS-2B cells could alleviate M2 macrophages polarization by modulated EVs, and eventually relieve the EMT process of BEAS-2B cells themselves under COPD pathogenesis, revealing a novel compensatory role of them in COPD. © 2019 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
Key words: Extracellular vesicle; Exosome; COPD; miR-21; M2 macrophages; Epithelial–mesenchymal transition; Small airway remodeling
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), one of the most common chronic lung disease, mainly features progressive and irreversible airflow limitation.1 Cigarette smoke (CS) is widely considered as a primary cause of COPD, directly damaging the functions of bronchial epithelial cells (BECs) which are the first anatomical airway barrier against noxious parcels and gases2 and resulting in excessive inflammatory responses. These inflammatory reactions might lead to many abnormal structural changes in COPD, such as epithelial–mesenchymal transition (EMT)-based narrowing of small airways (also named small airway
This project was funded by grants from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant Nos. 81770042, 81500033).
⁎Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: xyelyhua@163.com, (L. Xie),
sunsh311@hotmail.com. (S. Sun).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nano.2019.03.010 1549-9634/© 2019 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
Please cite this article as: He S, et al, Bronchial epithelial cell extracellular vesic alleviating .... Nanomedicine: NBM 2019;18:259-271, https://doi.org/10.1016/j
remodeling).3 However, the exact regulatory mechanisms of the EMT process in COPD remain unclear.
Previously, researchers reported that the accumulation of myofibroblasts might alter the components of the extracellular matrix, giving rise to the structural changes in lungs and other organs.4–6 There are many sources of myofibroblasts, including resident fibroblast to myofibroblast transition, airway smooth muscle to myofibroblast transition, EMT and the recruitment of circulating fibroblastic stem cells,7 and among them, EMTmight be one of the most crucial sources. Furthermore, many studies also reported that EMT is associated with small airway remodeling.8,9 Generally speaking, many cytokines could contribute to the development of EMT, such as transforming growth factor beta (TGF-β), fibroblast growth factor 2, connective tissue growth factor and insulin-like growth factor 2.10 Among those EMT-related cytokines, TGF-β is also considered a typical product of M2 macrophages, which are
les ameliorate epithelial–mesenchymal transition in COPD pathogenesis by .nano.2019.03.010
therefore in turn considered to be directly connected to the EMT process.11,12
Extracellular vesicles (EVs), such as exosomes (usually 30 nm150 nm in diameter,) and microvesicles (usually 200 nm-1000 nm in diameter), composed of a phospholipid bilayer, can be secreted by many cells, including epithelial cells, dendritic cells, mast cells macrophages, etc.13 EVs have been recently recognized as a novel cell-to-cell communication method for nucleic acids, proteins encapsulation and delivery functions.14 In this manner, the EVsreceiving cells could thereforemake different responses according to the EVs' content.15,16 As one of the most common cargo of EVs, microRNAs could participate in many inflammatory lung diseases' pathogenesis17; thus, it is reasonable to make a hypothesis that EVs could influence the occurrence of those inflammatory lung diseases through the contained microRNAs.
MiR-21 is a promising research element for its multi-functional roles in many diseases, especially in tumor related diseases.18,19 However, many researchers reported that miR-21 could also be related to various inflammatory diseases,20–22 including many pulmonary inflammatory diseases23–25 by targeting specific pathways, thereby regulating the expression of related key signals. Notably, one of the most important ways miR-21 functions, in both tumor and non-tumor diseases, is by affecting the EMT process.26 This concept has been confirmed bymany other researchers. Yang et al found that miR-21 promotes high glucose-induced human peritoneal mesothelial cells EMT by targeting phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN).27 Moreover, Wu et al reported that, in breast cancer, miR-21 could also target PTEN/AKT pathway, inducing EMT.28 In our previous studies, miR-21 was found to be higher in the serumof healthy smokers in comparisonwithCOPD patients,29 an observation further confirmed by our following in vivo studies. Furthermore, it was found that the level of miR-21 in the lungs is positively correlated to the severity of COPD.30 Additionally, we reported that the proportion of M2 macrophages was enhanced in both alveolar and peripheral blood in a COPD mouse model and this might also be an indicator of the COPD severity.31,32
In this investigation, a novel mechanism of how bronchial epithelial cells compensate for the EMT process under cigarette smoke extract (CSE) stress by modifying their EVs' content is presented for the first time.

sections.heading: Clinic samples
sections.text:
Five diagnosed COPD patients in stable phase from the Respiratory Medicine Department and 5 healthy volunteers from the Health Management Center (The Third Xiangya Hospital of Central South University, China) were enrolled in the present study (Table 1). All the COPD patients meet the diagnostic criteria according to guidelines from the Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease.33 The healthy participants had no smoking history, no tumor history and no other related chronic lung diseases (e.g., bronchiectasis, asthma, pulmonary cystic fibrosis, etc.). The enrolled COPD patients had similar characteristics. 10 ml peripheral blood was drawn from each participant and centrifuged at 3000 ×g for 15 min to segregate the serum. All the
collected serum samples were stored at −80 °C for further analyses. This study was approved by the Institutional Review Board of The Third Xiangya Hospital of Central South University following the guiding principles for research involving animals and humans.34 Each participant signed an informed consent.
Mouse COPD model building
The mouse COPD model method was previously developed by our group.30 Briefly, a total of 20 C57BL/6 mice (Vital River Laboratory Animal Technology Co., Ltd. Beijing, China) were enrolled in the present study and equally divided into control and model groups. The COPD animal model takes 28 days to develop. The mice were exposed to CS for two cycles per day except on days 1, 12 and 23 (for intraperitoneal injection). No treatment was performed on the control group. On days 1, 12 and 23, the control group was given an intraperitoneal injection of PBS (0.3 mL/20 g), while the model group was given an intraperitoneal injection of 100% CSE (0.3 mL/20 g; preparation method is described in the following paragraph). On day 29, all mice were anesthetized intraperitoneally with ketamine–xylazine (5 mg/kg) and sacrificed by cervical dislocation. Lungs were then collected for further analyses.

sections.heading: Preparation of CSE
sections.text: The preparation method of CSE was previously described.30 Briefly, each non-filtered Furong cigarette (tar: 13 mg, nicotine: 1.0 mg, carbon monoxide: 14 mg/cigarette; China Tobacco Hunan Industrial Co. Ltd., China) was burned and the smoke fully dissolved in 4 ml PBS as the original CSE (100% concentration) and filtered with a 0.22 μm filter (Millipore, USA) before being utilized. The CSE used for each experiment was freshly produced and used within 30 min.

sections.heading: Immunohistochemical (IHC) staining
sections.text: The mice lung protein expression level of E-cadherin (1:100, Proteintech, USA), N-Cadherin (1:100, Proteintech, USA) and Vimentin (1:50, Proteintech, USA) was detected by immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining (4 °C overnight) and visualized by diaminobenzidine (DAB, Sigma, USA). The IHC staining images were further measured by Image-Pro Plus version 6.0 software (Media Cybernetics Inc., USA) using integrated optical density (IOD) /area methods.35

sections.heading: Cell culture
sections.text:
BEAS-2B cells (supplied by Prof. Fuqiang Wen and Dr. Ni Zeng from the West China Hospital of Sichuan University), the
bronchial derived epithelial cells which were always utilized as the representative of normal bronchial epithelial cells36,37 were cultured with Dulbecco's modified eagle medium (Gibco, USA) plus 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS, Gibco, USA) in an incubator at constant temperature 5% CO2, 37 °C. THP-1 cells, a human monocytic cell line derived from an acute monocytic leukemia patient, were bought from American Type Culture Collection (ATCC) and cultured with RPMI-1640 medium (Gibco, USA) and 10% FBS (Gibco, USA). Otetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate (PMA, 100 ng/ml, Sigma, USA) was added to THP-1 cells for 48 h to generate M0 macrophages.

sections.heading: Isolation of EVs
sections.text: The serum EVs from both COPD patients and healthy people were isolated utilizing ExoQuick™ (System Biosciences, USA) EVs isolation kit according to the user's protocol.38 Briefly, serum samples were centrifuged at 3000 ×g for 15 min to eliminate cell debris. The supernatants were then collected and added with the ExoQuick™ reagent (4:1) and incubated at 4 °C for 30 min followed by centrifuging at 1500 ×g for 30 min. The supernatants were removed and pellets resuspended in 100 μl

sections.heading: PBS.
sections.text:
The EVs of BEAS-2B cells were isolated from the cell supernatants (FBS-free) utilizing ExoQuick-TC™ (System Biosciences, USA) using amodified protocol.39 Briefly, completemedium was removed and cells washed with PBS 5 times to eliminate the remaining FBS and EVs. DMEMwith 0.5% bovine serum albumin (BSA, Boehringer Ingelheim, Germany) was added to BEAS-2B cells and after 24 h samples were collected for EVs isolation. The collected supernatant was centrifuged at 300 ×g for 5 min to remove dead cells and then at 2000 ×g for 20 min to remove cell debris and another 10,000 ×g for 20 min to remove other large vesicles. Those centrifuged supernatants were filtered with a 0.22 μm filter (Millipore, USA) and ultra-filtered utilizing a 100 kDa ultrafiltration device (Amicon Ultra-15, Millipore, USA) to eliminate microparticles. The final supernatants (upper side) were 5-fold concentrated. The EVs were quantified by Bicinchoninic Acid Assay (BCA, Beyotime Bio, China).
Identification of serum and cell supernatant EVs
EVs imaging was performed utilizing transmission electronic microscopy (TEM, Tecnai™ G2 Spirit 120KV, USA). The EVs size distribution was analyzed utilizing Nanoparticle Tracking Analysis (NTA) system (ZetaView™120, Particle Metrix, Germany). The EVs protein markers CD9 (1:500, Proteintech, USA) and CD81 (1:1000, Abcam, USA) of serum EVs were detected by western blotting (WB, described in the following paragraph). The protein markers CD81 (BD Bioscience, USA) and CD63 (BD Bioscience, USA) of BEAS-2B EVs were detected by flow cytometry (Accuri™ C6 flow cytometer, BD Bioscience, USA).40

sections.heading: Cell apoptosis assay
sections.text:
Cell apoptosis of the BEAS-2B cells was detected with a flow cytometry method using an Annexin V-PI Apoptosis Detection Kit (BD Bioscience, USA). Briefly, cells were collected, washed with
PBS, and suspended in 500 μl of binding buffer. The cells were incubated with Annexin V and Propidium Iodide (PI) at room temperature for 10 min. The relative quantitative apoptosis was analyzed using BD Cyan flow cytometer (BD Bioscience, USA). Further analysis was performed using FlowJo software (Tree Star Inc., USA).
Real-time reverse transcription quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) analysis
The total RNA of both EVs and BEAS-2B cells was isolated by TRIzol reagent (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) following the manufacturer's protocol. Reverse transcription process was then performed utilizing PrimeScript™ RT Reagent Kit (Takara, Japan). Then, the relative expression level of RNAs was detected by SYBR Green PCRMaster Mix (Bio-Rad, USA) quantified by two-step quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR, Applied Biosystems, USA). U6 and GAPDH were utilized as the internal controls of miR-21 and other mRNAs respectively. The 2−△△CT method was employed to analyze the results. The primer of miR-21 is Bulge-Loop™ (RiboBio, China) and the other primers of mRNAs are presented in Table 2.

sections.heading: Internalization of BEAS-2B-derived EVs and the contents
sections.text:
To determine the internalization process of BEAS-2B-derived EVs by macrophages, EVs were resuspended with PBS and stained with green fluorescent dye PKH67 (Sigma, USA), as described before.41 After, these were re-isolated by the same EVe isolation method using ExoQuick-TC™ (System Biosciences, USA). The PKH67dyed-PBS (without EVs)was utilized as control, undergoing the same re-isolation method. The dyed EVs (50 μg/ml) or dyed PBSwas incubatedwith THP-1 derivedmacrophages, respectively, in a constant temperature incubator at 5% CO2, 37 °C for 6 h. After that, the macrophages were washed 3 times with PBS and fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde before the nuclei were dyed with DAPI (Sigma, USA). The green fluorescent signals in cells, indicating the internalized EVs, were observed by fluorescence microscopy.
To detect the transfection of miR-21 via BEAS-2B EVs, the macrophages were incubated with the non-dyed EVs and PBS, respectively, for 6 h before being harvested for the further miR-21 RT-qPCR reaction.
Western blot (WB) of lung tissues and cells
EVs and cells were homogenized manually in a glass homogenizer and lysed in RIPA lysate for 30 min on ice and were then being quantified by BCA (Beyotime-Bio, China), respectively. Specific antibodies (TGF-β: 1:800, Proteintech, USA; Arg-1: 1:4000, Abcam, USA; IL-10: 1:1000, Proteintech, USA; β-actin: 1:5000, Proteintech, USA; E-Cadherin: 1:1000, Cell Signaling Technology, USA; N-Cadherin: 1:1000, Proteintech, USA; Vimentin: 1:1000, Cell Signaling Technology, USA) were used for the proteins blotting and were revealed by
secondary anti-rabbit antibody with horseradish peroxidase conjugate (1:3000, 1 h).

sections.heading: MicroRNA interference
sections.text: THP-1 derived M0 macrophages in the exponential phase of growth were plated in 24-well plates at 5 × 104 cells/plate and cultured for 24 h. Then, the cells were transfected with the miR-21 mimics (5 nM, Qiagen, Germany) or miR-21 inhibitors (5 nM, Qiagen, Germany) using HiPerFect™ Transfection reagents (Qiagen, Germany) and RPMI-1640 complete medium, according to the manufacturer's protocol.

sections.heading: Flow cytometry of cells
sections.text: THP-1 cells derived M0 macrophages (transfected with or without miR-21 mimics and inhibitors) were treated with EVs (50 μg/ml) or PBS for 48 h and then incubated with CD206 flow cytometry antibody (BD Bioscience, USA), following the guide protocol and tested using a BD Cyan flow cytometer (BD Bioscience, USA). Further analysis was performed using FlowJo software (Tree Star Inc., USA).

sections.heading: Co-culture procedures
sections.text:
The macrophages and BEAS-2B cells were co-cultured utilizing the Transwell™ cell culture inserts (Corning, USA) with a 0.4 μm pore sized membrane, following the protocol described previously with some modifications.42 Briefly, on day 1, THP-1 cells (1 × 106 cells/well) were seeded on the upper side of
the co-culture system with PMA (100 ng/ml) for 48 h. On day 3, the THP-1 differentiated into M0 macrophages and the supernatant was replaced with normal complete medium for 24 h to eliminate the effect of PMA.On day 4,M0macrophages were incubatedwith EVs (50 μg/ml) for 48 h. On day 5, BEAS-2B cells were seeded into a 6- well plate (1 × 106 cells/well). On day 6, the inserts of M0 macrophageswere put into the 6-well plate ofBEAS-2Band co-cultured for 48 h before the BEAS-2B cells were harvested for further analyses.

sections.heading: Statistical analysis
sections.text: SPSS 22.0 statistical software (IBM Corporation, USA) and are presented as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM). The statistical difference between groups was examined using nonparametric Mann–Whitney U test and a one-way ANOVA test. P b 0.05 was considered as statistically significant.

sections.heading: Results
sections.text:
Characteristics and the miR-21 level of serum EVs from COPD patients
It was shown by TEM that the EVs are with the cup- or sphereshaped morphology (Figure 1, A). The surface markers (CD9 and CD81) of the EVswere confirmed byWB (Figure 1,B).Moreover, the size distribution, identified by nanoparticle tracking analysis (NTA), showed the EVs to be in the 50-150 nm (mainly exosomes) range in diameter (Figure 1, C). Additionally, the level of miR-21 in the EVs of COPD patients was significantly higher than healthy people (Figure 1, D).
Epithelial–mesenchymal transition process of COPD mouse model lungs
Mice lungs were collected on day 29 for further analyses. We confirmed by both IHC staining (Figure 2, A, B) and WB
(Figure 2, C, D) that the epithelial marker (E-cadherin) was decreased and the mesenchymal markers (N-Cadherin and Vimentin) were both increased in the COPD model mice group. These changes were mainly in the bronchial epithelial cells (Figure 2, A).

sections.heading: Characteristics of BEAS-2B EVs
sections.text:
Similar to serum EVs, EVs of BEAS-2B cells presented comparable morphology and size distribution (Figure 3, A). The surface markers of BEAS-2B EVs (CD81 and CD63) were detected by flow cytometry (Figure 3, D).
Influence of CSE on apoptosis and level of EVs miR-21 in BEAS-2B cells
CSE at different concentrations – 0%, 1%, 3%, 5%, 8%, 10% – was added to BEAS-2B cells and the apoptotic cells percentage detected by flowcytometry (Figure 4,A-F).No significant differences
were found among BEAS-2B cells treated with CSE of 0%, 1%, 3% and 5%. Instead, 8% and 10% CSE showed a significant increase in the apoptotic cells percentage of BEAS-2B cells (Figure 4, G). Furthermore, in comparison to 0%CSE group, the 1%, 3% and 5% CSE reduced the EVs miR-21 level of BEAS-2B cells; however, this was not the case for the 8% and 10% CSE (Figure 4, H).
EVs as carriers of miR-21 from BEAS-2B cells to macrophages
EVs were dyed with PKH67 (Sigma, USA) and incubated with THP-1 derived macrophages for 6 h respectively. Then, those macrophages were dyed with DAPI (Sigma, USA) and observed by a fluorescence microscope. The green fluorescence signal indicated
EVs internalized by macrophages (Figure 5, A). Moreover, EVs of 0% CSE- and 5% CSE-treated BEAS-2B cells were incubated with macrophages. Results showed the level of miR-21 in macrophages incubated with EVs of 5% CSE-treated BEAS-2B cells was decreased compared with the EVs of 0% CSE-treated BEAS-2B cells, but higher than the PBS treated group (Figure 5, B).
EVs miR-21 promotes the M2 macrophage polarization
THP-1 presented as rounded cells in suspension (Figure 6, A). They could be differentiated into adherent spindle-shaped macrophages by PMA (Figure 6, B). Moreover, when EVs were added, the THP-1 derived macrophages further spread cellular pseudopodia (Figure 6, C, D).
To analyze the role of miR-21 in M2 macrophage polarization, miR-21 mimics and inhibitors were employed
together with 5% CSE-EVs. Results showed the M2-directed polarization was amplified by miR-21 mimics and partly blocked by the inhibitors. These results were confirmed by flow cytometry (Figure 6, E, F) for M2 surface marker CD206 and RT-qPCR (Figure 6, G) and WB (Figure 6, H, I) for M2-related cytokines (TGF-β, Arg-1 and IL-10).
0% CSE-EXO treated macrophages contribute to EMT of BEAS-2B cells
After the co-culture procedure of macrophages and BEAS-2B cells (Figure 7, A), it was shown that E-Cadherin was increased in 5% CSE-EXO treated macrophages group, while N-Cadherin and Vimentin were decreased, in comparison with the 0% CSEEXO treated macrophage group, at both gene (Figure 7, B) and protein level (Figure 7, C, D).

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text:
The present study consolidated the pathogenic role of miR-21 in COPD in promoting EMT in bronchial epithelial cells via macrophage polarization. More importantly, as the level of total serum EVs miR-21 in COPD patients increases, bronchial epithelial cells were shown to reduce the level of their EVs miR-21 to compensate for the pathogenic effects of increased EVs miR-21 from other sources. In this manuscript, for the first time, a novel self-compensatory role of EVs in COPD pathogenesis is presented.
As the dominant element in COPD pathogenesis, CS contains numerous toxicmaterials and noxious particles which could directly cause disorders in lung, especially the microRNA expression profiles.43,44 According to Momi and colleagues, this could result from some epigenetic disruption, such as DNA methylation and genetic alterations.45 In this study, similarly, we confirmed an
increased level of serum EVs miR-21 in COPD patients. The serum EVs could be a total of all the other cells derived EVs, macroscopically reflecting the changes of their contents. This result indicates that CSE exposure might influence not only the cellular or lung tissue miR-21 level,29,30,46 but also the serum EVs. However, when we focused on a single cell type, the miR-21 level was decreased in BEAS-2B EVs in 5% CSE exposure, indicating the BEAS-2B cellswereworking against the overall trendswhen treated with CSE. As reported by many researchers, EVs could play multifunctional roles in the internalmicroenvironment. For instance, those tumor cells derived EVs always tend to work in a pathogenic way. Shan and colleagues found that EVs from nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC), under hypoxic conditions, were overloaded with matrix metalloproteinase-13 (MMP-13), leading to enhanced migration and invasiveness and inducing microenvironment changes to promote NPC aggressiveness.47 In a similar manner, the hypoxic tumor-derived EVs contained more miR-301a,
promoting pancreatic cancer metastasis by influencing tumor associated macrophages polarization.15 On the other hand, those stem cells derived EVs could act in a therapeutic way. Adiposederived stem cells could control obesity-associated inflammation andmetabolic disorders by EVswithmodifiedmicroRNAprofile.16 Besides, mesenchymal stromal cell EVs were found to be able to alleviate the hyperoxia induced bronchopulmonary dysplasia by blunting related inflammation and immune response, still, resulting from the modified EVs contents.48 All these results above indicate that it is the contents of the EVs thatmake themmulti-functional and this concept is in line with our results. Although we observed an increased level of EVs miR-21 in 8% or 10% CSE, this is not a normal way of EVs secretion and would lead to an unauthentic result. 8% or 10% CSE could cause an obvious enhancement of the apoptotic cell percentage, whichmight give rise to an uncontrollable release of other extracellular vesicles from the dead cell and therefore influence the observing of the actual EVs contents.
Notably, M2 macrophages were recently considered to be the primary active phenotype in COPD.49 In this study, we confirmed that macrophages could uptake BEAS-2B EVs and be polarized into an M2 phenotype by EVs miR-21 in COPD pathogenesis. Similar results were also reported by other researchers15,16 for other diseases. According to them, those EVs miR-21 might take effect through targeting PTEN/PI3Kgamma pathway or the phosphorylation process of STAT3. As was found by us that the proportion of M2 macrophages was negatively correlated with the lung function of mouse COPD models, it is reasonable to speculate that EVs from the CSE-treated BEAS-2B cells could play a compensatory role by reducing their EVs miR-21 which could therefore decrease the M2 macrophage proportion.
An obvious EMT process was observed in the lungs of mouse COPD models in the present study, in line with many previous studies.50–52 Furthermore, when the 0% CSE-EVs- and 5% CSEEVs- polarized macrophages were co-cultured with other BEAS-2B cells respectively, the former resulted in severer EMT in BEAS-2B cells becau EMT process partly through the TLR4/IL-10 pathway.53 Moreover, Shen and colleagues found that M2macrophages could promote EMT process by TGF-β1 in renal fibrosis54 which is similar to what we found previously - an increased TGF-β in alveolar M2 macrophages in COPD31. These results indicating, in the present study, that those EVs-polarizedM2macrophages could promote EMT in BEAS-2B cells by TGF-β.
Several recent studies showed that EVs play crucial roles in COPD. Benedikter and colleagues found that EVs from CSEtreated bronchial epithelial cells could affect the inflammation process of both smokers and ex-smokers.36 Moreover, Yu Fujita and colleagues reported that EVs could also promote the EMT process in lungs of COPD patients by affecting the autophage process.37 Furthermore, Kim and colleagues also demonstrated the therapeutic role of EVs from adipose stem cells in the development of emphysema.55 In our investigation, we have demonstrated that the contents of EVs could be modified according to the exposure of COPD pathogeneses, therefore compensating for the following pathological changes.
However, there are some limitations in the present study that merit mentioning. Firstly, aswaswidely reported, EVs containmany agents other than the targets of interest investigated in this study. This should be considered in future investigations by performing a
complementary gene sequencing or proteomics of the EVs. Moreover, although the EVs TEM images in the present study could provide a clear structure of the EVs isolated, images with multiple EVs would be advantageous, as it could provide more detailed information of the sample. Additionally, regarding the coculture of M2 macrophages and BEAS-2B cells, we set two groups, which are both treated with EVs, for the reason that, in real world, macrophages are supposed to be always under the influences of EVs. However, to be more rigorous, an extra PBS-treated macrophage group could be better to measure the specific effects of M2 macrophages. Furthermore, one more western blot of TGF-β in the co-culturedBEAS-2B cells couldmake the results more confidential as it could give more information about where the TGF-β came from, leading the EMT process of BEAS-2B cells.
In summary, BEAS-2B cells were shown to indirectly modulate the EMT process in the COPD pathogenesis by alleviating the polarization of M2 macrophages via reducing their EVs miR-21 level, revealing a novel compensatory role of EVs in COPD.

sections.heading: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sections.text: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nano.2019.03.010.

referenceMentions.context: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), one of the most common chronic lung disease, mainly features progressive and irreversible airflow limitation.(1) Cigarette smoke (CS) is widely considered as a primary cause of COPD, directly damaging the functions of bronchial epithelial cells (BECs) which are the first anatomical airway barrier against noxious parcels and gases(2) and resulting in excessive inflammatory responses.
1016/j remodeling).(3) However, the exact regulatory mechanisms of the EMT process in COPD remain unclear.

Furthermore, many studies also reported that EMT is associated with small airway remodeling.(8,9) Generally speaking, many cytokines could contribute to the development of EMT, such as transforming growth factor beta (TGF-β), fibroblast growth factor 2, connective tissue growth factor and insulin-like growth factor 2.

MiR-21 is a promising research element for its multi-functional roles in many diseases, especially in tumor related diseases.(18,19) However, many researchers reported that miR-21 could also be related to various inflammatory diseases, including many pulmonary inflammatory diseases by targeting specific pathways, thereby regulating the expression of related key signals.

MiR-21 is a promising research element for its multi-functional roles in many diseases, especially in tumor related diseases.(18,19) However, many researchers reported that miR-21 could also be related to various inflammatory diseases, including many pulmonary inflammatory diseases by targeting specific pathways, thereby regulating the expression of related key signals.
Notably, one of the most important ways miR-21 functions, in both tumor and non-tumor diseases, is by affecting the EMT process.(26) This concept has been confirmed bymany other researchers.

Yang et al found that miR-21 promotes high glucose-induced human peritoneal mesothelial cells EMT by targeting phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN).(27) Moreover, Wu et al reported that, in breast cancer, miR-21 could also target PTEN/AKT pathway, inducing EMT.

Moreover, Wu et al reported that, in breast cancer, miR-21 could also target PTEN/AKT pathway, inducing EMT.(28) In our previous studies, miR-21 was found to be higher in the serumof healthy smokers in comparisonwithCOPD patients,(29) an observation further confirmed by our following in vivo studies.

Furthermore, it was found that the level of miR-21 in the lungs is positively correlated to the severity of COPD.(30) Additionally, we reported that the proportion of M2 macrophages was enhanced in both alveolar and peripheral blood in a COPD mouse model and this might also be an indicator of the COPD severity.

Additionally, we reported that the proportion of M2 macrophages was enhanced in both alveolar and peripheral blood in a COPD mouse model and this might also be an indicator of the COPD severity.(31,32) In this investigation, a novel mechanism of how bronchial epithelial cells compensate for the EMT process under cigarette smoke extract (CSE) stress by modifying their EVs' content is presented for the first time.

The serum EVs from both COPD patients and healthy people were isolated utilizing ExoQuickTM (System Biosciences, USA) EVs isolation kit according to the user's protocol.(38) Briefly, serum samples were centrifuged at 3000 ×g for 15 min to eliminate cell debris.

The EVs of BEAS-2B cells were isolated from the cell supernatants (FBS-free) utilizing ExoQuick-TCTM (System Biosciences, USA) using amodified protocol.(39) Briefly, completemedium was removed and cells washed with PBS 5 times to eliminate the remaining FBS and EVs.
The protein markers CD81 (BD Bioscience, USA) and CD63 (BD Bioscience, USA) of BEAS-2B EVs were detected by flow cytometry (AccuriTM C6 flow cytometer, BD Bioscience, USA).(40)

To determine the internalization process of BEAS-2B-derived EVs by macrophages, EVs were resuspended with PBS and stained with green fluorescent dye PKH67 (Sigma, USA), as described before.(41) After, these were re-isolated by the same EVe isolation method using ExoQuick-TCTM (System Biosciences, USA).

Shan and colleagues found that EVs from nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC), under hypoxic conditions, were overloaded with matrix metalloproteinase-13 (MMP-13), leading to enhanced migration and invasiveness and inducing microenvironment changes to promote NPC aggressiveness.(47) In a similar manner, the hypoxic tumor-derived EVs contained more miR-301a,

Adiposederived stem cells could control obesity-associated inflammation andmetabolic disorders by EVswithmodifiedmicroRNAprofile.(16) Besides, mesenchymal stromal cell EVs were found to be able to alleviate the hyperoxia induced bronchopulmonary dysplasia by blunting related inflammation and immune response, still, resulting from the modified EVs contents.

Besides, mesenchymal stromal cell EVs were found to be able to alleviate the hyperoxia induced bronchopulmonary dysplasia by blunting related inflammation and immune response, still, resulting from the modified EVs contents.(48) All these results above indicate that it is the contents of the EVs thatmake themmulti-functional and this concept is in line with our results.

Notably, M2 macrophages were recently considered to be the primary active phenotype in COPD.(49) In this study, we confirmed that macrophages could uptake BEAS-2B EVs and be polarized into an M2 phenotype by EVs miR-21 in COPD pathogenesis.

Furthermore, when the 0% CSE-EVs- and 5% CSEEVs- polarized macrophages were co-cultured with other BEAS-2B cells respectively, the former resulted in severer EMT in BEAS-2B cells becau EMT process partly through the TLR4/IL-10 pathway.(53) Moreover, Shen and colleagues found that M2macrophages could promote EMT process by TGF-β1 in renal fibrosis(54) which is similar to what we found previously - an increased TGF-β in alveolar M2 macrophages in COPD(31).

Benedikter and colleagues found that EVs from CSEtreated bronchial epithelial cells could affect the inflammation process of both smokers and ex-smokers.(36) Moreover, Yu Fujita and colleagues reported that EVs could also promote the EMT process in lungs of COPD patients by affecting the autophage process.

Moreover, Yu Fujita and colleagues reported that EVs could also promote the EMT process in lungs of COPD patients by affecting the autophage process.(37) Furthermore, Kim and colleagues also demonstrated the therapeutic role of EVs from adipose stem cells in the development of emphysema.

Furthermore, Kim and colleagues also demonstrated the therapeutic role of EVs from adipose stem cells in the development of emphysema.(55) In our investigation, we have demonstrated that the contents of EVs could be modified according to the exposure of COPD pathogeneses, therefore compensating for the following pathological changes.

metadata.abstractText: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is partly characterized as epithelial–mesenchymal transition (EMT)-related airflow limitation. Extracellular vesicles (EVs) play crucial roles in the crosstalk between cells, affecting many diseases including COPD. Up to now, the roles of EVs in COPD are still debated. As we found in this investigation, COPD patients have higher miR-21 level in total serum EVs. EMT occurs in lungs of COPD mice. Furthermore, bronchial epithelial cells (BEAS-2B) could generate EVs with less miR-21 when treated with cigarette smoke extract (CSE), impacting less on the M2-directed macrophage polarization than the control-EVs (PBS-treated) according to EVs miR-21 level. Furthermore, the EMT processes in BEAS-2B cells were enhanced with the M2 macrophages proportion when co-cultured. Collectively, these results demonstrate that CSE-treated BEAS-2B cells could alleviate M2 macrophages polarization by modulated EVs, and eventually relieve the EMT process of BEAS-2B cells themselves under COPD pathogenesis, revealing a novel compensatory role of them in COPD. © 2019 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
